name: Cancer Biology

prereqs.text: (03-221 [] at least D) or (03-220 [] at least D) or (03-330 [] at least D)

long_desc: Cancer affects roughly 1 in 3 people worldwide, and originates from both hereditary as well as environmental causes. Its prevalence makes it practically inescapable. Its of great relevance from both scientific and sociocultural perspectives. This course aims to examine various hallmarks of the biology of cancer while exploring novel concepts that challenge our understanding of cell biology. From the perspective of a cancer cell, we will learn about basic concepts of cell division, DNA replication, cell signaling, cell cycle control, cell metabolism, the regulation of gene expression in human cells, oncogenes, tumor suppressor genes, mutations, the process of metastasis, cancer diagnosis, cancer treatments and ethical questions surrounding treating patients, the epidemiology of cancer including prevalence and historical trends in diagnosis, as well as social impacts of a cancer diagnosis. Students will also explore the primary literature and scientific review articles to better understand research and methods of investigation into the cellular and molecular processes of tumorigenesis. This course will include interactive lectures, guest speakers, and in class discussion exercises aimed at building class participation and association, as well as confidence in public speaking about the sciences. Given the welldocumented link between stress and cancer, there will also be a small component aimed at making students aware of health and wellness, such as reducing stress and anxiety.

custom_fields.goals: Upon completion of this course, you should be able to1 Conceptually describe the phenotypic differences between a normal versus a cancer cell.2 Discuss different types of genetic, environmental, and epigenetic causes of cancer in terms of important sources of DNA damage and altered cell function related to cancer initiation.3 Articulate some of the cellular and molecular strategies, including DNA damage, cell cycle control, DNA repair, apoptosis, altered metabolism, and metastasis, employed by cancer cells during the tumorigenic process, which includes initiation, promotion, and progression.4 Compare the function of oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes and how cancer cells alter these during cancer initiation and progression.5 Articulate the complexities of cancer treatment from the scientific and ethicalsocial perspectives. Also, understand how cancer treatments kill cancer cells, and how treatments impact the body, mind and life of the patient.6 Read primary articles, grasp the hypothesis tested, capture the key findings, and critically assess the value of the studies and their impact on cancer therapeutics. From this, students can join conversations related to recent scientific research discoveries in cancer biology and gain an appreciation for the challenges of performing cancer research and taking that research to the bedside.

custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Students should have a foundational knowledge of genetics and cell biology. Knowledge of immunology and molecular biology is highly desired.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: weekly quizzes; 2 written assignments; final team project; participation/attendance is significant % of final grade
custom_fields.relevance: Students will develop skills in reading, interpreting, analyzing, and communicating about the primary literature in cancer research. This transferable skill will prepare students for graduate school and medical school.
